item.description:
We have decided to move to the first volume of the Capital. For this first meetings let's read Part1 which ends at page 102 (in http://www.marxists.org/archive/marx/works/download/pdf/Capital-Volume-I.pdf).

Thank you very much Jim(Williams) for your suggestion:

Almost all of Marx's writings are critical or descriptive, usually on Hegelian philosophy, Economics and Capitalism. He rarely makes any proscriptive comments. I have been approaching this next meeting trying to more fully understand his recommendations, if any, for a post-revolutionary Marxists society. He does not talk about it often and when he does it is usually in very general terms. The two short works we are reading are probably his most extensive treatments of these ideas. I have been digging around to see what else might contribute to our understanding of this issue and have found a few more short commentaries. They are only about a page or two, but I think they work well with the two works we are reading and would contribute to creating a better and more complete understanding of a post-revolutionary Marxists society. 

 

I know it is a bit late but if you think it would contribute to the discussion please feel free to pass them along to the group:

 

Marx & Engels-Demands of the Communist Party in Germany (1848)

http://www.marxists.org/archive/marx/works/1848/03/24.htm


Marx & Engels-Address to the Central Committee of the Communist League (1850)

http://www.marxists.org/archive/marx/works/1847/communist-league/1850-ad1.htm

Marx-Conspectus of Bakunin’s Statism and Anarchy (1874)

http://www.marxists.org/archive/marx/works/1874/04/bakunin-notes.htm
